title: Cerebral Angiography
description: A diagnostic X-ray procedure that uses contrast dye to visualize cerebral arteries and veins.

faqs.question: How long does the test take?
faqs.answer: Usually 30–60 minutes depending on complexity.

faqs.question: Is it painful?
faqs.answer: Only mild discomfort at puncture site with local anesthesia.

title: Carotid Artery Stenting
description: Minimally invasive placement of a stent in the carotid artery to prevent stroke.

faqs.question: Do I need general anesthesia?
faqs.answer: No, the procedure is usually done under local anesthesia.

faqs.question: How long is hospital stay?
faqs.answer: Most patients are discharged within 1–2 days.

title: Intracranial Aneurysm Coiling
description: Endovascular placement of coils to block blood flow into an aneurysm and prevent rupture.

faqs.question: Are coils permanent?
faqs.answer: Yes, they remain inside permanently.

faqs.question: Is it safer than surgery?
faqs.answer: In many cases, yes. It is less invasive than open surgery.

title: AVM Embolization
description: Minimally invasive procedure to block abnormal blood vessels in the brain (arteriovenous malformations).

faqs.question: Can AVM be cured with embolization?
faqs.answer: Sometimes yes, but often it is combined with surgery or radiosurgery.

faqs.question: How long is recovery?
faqs.answer: Usually a few days depending on complexity.

title: Mechanical Thrombectomy
description: An emergency procedure to remove a blood clot from a brain artery in acute ischemic stroke.

faqs.question: What is the time window?
faqs.answer: Usually effective within 6–24 hours of stroke onset.

faqs.question: Does it reverse paralysis?
faqs.answer: It can improve recovery chances significantly.

title: Spinal Angiography
description: Imaging of spinal cord blood vessels using contrast and X-rays.

faqs.question: Is it risky?
faqs.answer: It has some risk but is very safe in expert hands.

faqs.question: Does it need admission?
faqs.answer: Yes, usually for observation overnight.

title: Vertebroplasty
description: Injection of bone cement into fractured vertebra to relieve pain and stabilize spine.

faqs.question: Does it relieve pain immediately?
faqs.answer: Yes, many patients feel relief within 24 hours.

faqs.question: Is it done under general anesthesia?
faqs.answer: No, usually local anesthesia with sedation.

title: Kyphoplasty
description: A balloon is inserted into collapsed vertebra and filled with cement to restore height and stability.

faqs.question: Is it better than vertebroplasty?
faqs.answer: Kyphoplasty restores vertebral height, while vertebroplasty does not.

faqs.question: Is hospital stay required?
faqs.answer: Most cases are discharged next day.

title: CSF Leak Repair
description: Minimally invasive repair of cerebrospinal fluid leaks using targeted sealants or patches.

faqs.question: What are symptoms of CSF leak?
faqs.answer: Severe positional headaches, nausea, clear nasal discharge.

faqs.question: Is repair permanent?
faqs.answer: Usually yes, though rare recurrences happen.

title: Brain Tumor Embolization
description: Blocking blood supply to brain tumors before surgery to reduce bleeding risk.

faqs.question: Does it cure the tumor?
faqs.answer: No, it reduces bleeding during surgery.

faqs.question: How long before surgery is it done?
faqs.answer: Usually within 1–2 days before surgery.
